First Time in Mexico Guide

Everything You Need to Know for Your First Trip

Last updated: January 2025

Welcome to Mexico! Whether you're dreaming of Caribbean beaches, ancient Mayan ruins, vibrant cities, or world-class cuisine, Mexico has it all—and it's closer, safer, and more affordable than you might think. This guide covers everything first-time visitors need to know, from choosing your destination to navigating cultural differences.

In This Guide

  • Why Mexico?
  • Where to Go First
  • Entry Requirements
  • Money Matters
  • Safety Reality Check
  • Cultural Essentials
  • Language Tips
  • Getting Around
  • Health & Hygiene
  • Packing Essentials
  • Common Mistakes to Avoid
  • Trip Planning Timeline
  • Best Time to Visit

Why Mexico?

{<strong>Top Reasons to Visit:</strong></p><p>1. <strong>Incredible Value:</strong> Your money goes far. Excellent food, comfortable hotels, and amazing experiences at a fraction of US/European prices.</p><p>2. <strong>Easy Access:</strong> Direct flights from most US cities (2-4 hours). No visa required for most nationalities (just a tourist permit on arrival).</p><p>3. <strong>Diverse Experiences:</strong> Beaches, mountains, deserts, jungles, colonial cities, ancient ruins, world-class food, vibrant culture—all in one country.</p><p>4. <strong>Rich Culture:</strong> UNESCO World Heritage sites, living indigenous traditions, Day of the Dead celebrations, incredible art and music.</p><p>5. <strong>Amazing Food:</strong> Mexican cuisine is UNESCO-recognized. Tacos, mole, ceviche, mezcal—eating is one of the best parts of any Mexico trip.</p><p>6. <strong>Warm People:</strong> Mexicans are genuinely welcoming. Basic Spanish efforts are rewarded with smiles and help.</p><p>7. <strong>Year-Round Destinations:</strong> Somewhere in Mexico has perfect weather every month of the year.}

Where to Go First

{<strong>Best First-Timer Destinations:</strong></p><p><strong>Cancún & Riviera Maya (Beach + Ruins)</strong></p><ul><li>Why: Easy resort experience, beautiful beaches, nearby Mayan ruins</p><ul><li>Best for: Beach lovers, families, all-inclusive seekers</p><ul><li>From US: 2-4 hour flights, many directs</p><p><strong>Mexico City (Culture + Food)</strong></p><ul><li>Why: World-class museums, incredible food scene, vibrant neighborhoods</p><ul><li>Best for: Culture seekers, foodies, urban explorers</p><ul><li>From US: 3-5 hour flights</p><p><strong>Puerto Vallarta (Beach + Town)</strong></p><ul><li>Why: Beautiful beaches plus charming downtown, Pacific Coast vibes</p><ul><li>Best for: Couples, those wanting beach + culture mix</p><ul><li>From US: 3-5 hour flights</p><p><strong>Oaxaca (Food + Culture)</strong></p><ul><li>Why: Food capital of Mexico, indigenous culture, mezcal</p><ul><li>Best for: Foodies, culture seekers, adventurous travelers</p><ul><li>From US: Fly through Mexico City</p><p><strong>San Miguel de Allende (Colonial Charm)</strong></p><ul><li>Why: Stunningly beautiful colonial city, arts scene, expat-friendly</p><ul><li>Best for: Art lovers, photographers, romantic getaways</p><ul><li>From US: Fly to León or Querétaro</p><p><strong>Los Cabos (Beach + Desert)</strong></p><ul><li>Why: Dramatic desert-meets-ocean landscape, luxury resorts, fishing</p><ul><li>Best for: Luxury seekers, golfers, sport fishing enthusiasts</p><ul><li>From US: 2-3 hour flights from West Coast}

Entry Requirements

{<strong>What You Need:</strong></p><p><strong>Passport:</strong> Valid passport required. Recommended 6+ months validity.</p><p><strong>Tourist Permit (FMM):</strong> Free permit allowing 180 days. Given on arrival (plane or border).</p><ul><li>Usually filled out on plane or at immigration</p><ul><li>Keep the paper/digital copy—you need it to leave!</p><ul><li>Airlines increasingly handle this digitally</p><p><strong>Visa:</strong> Most nationalities DON'T need a visa for tourism (up to 180 days):</p><ul><li>US, Canada, UK, EU, Australia, Japan, and 60+ countries</p><ul><li>Check your specific nationality at INM.gob.mx</p><p><strong>Return/Onward Ticket:</strong> Technically required. Airlines may ask for proof.</p><p><strong>NOT Required:</strong></p><ul><li>COVID vaccination (as of 2024)</p><ul><li>COVID tests (as of 2024)</p><ul><li>Travel insurance (but strongly recommended)</p><ul><li>Proof of accommodation (helpful but rarely asked)</p><p><strong>Customs Allowances:</strong></p><ul><li>$500 USD worth of goods (plus personal items)</p><ul><li>3 liters of alcohol</p><ul><li>200 cigarettes</p><ul><li>No fresh fruits, vegetables, meats}

Money Matters

{<strong>Currency: Mexican Peso (MXN)</strong></p><p><strong>Exchange Rate:</strong> Roughly 17-20 pesos = $1 USD (check current rates)</p><p><strong>Getting Money:</strong></p><ul><li>ATMs (cajeros) are everywhere and give best rates</p><ul><li>Use bank ATMs (Santander, HSBC, Citibanamex) not standalone machines</p><ul><li>Withdraw in pesos, not dollars</p><ul><li>Your bank may charge fees—consider a travel-friendly card (Schwab, Capital One)</p><p><strong>Paying:</strong></p><ul><li>Credit cards accepted at hotels, nice restaurants, stores</p><ul><li>Cash preferred at markets, tacos stands, small shops</p><ul><li>Always have cash for tips, taxis, small purchases</p><ul><li>Carry small bills—change can be scarce</p><p><strong>Costs (Approximate):</strong></p><ul><li>Taco: $1-2 USD</p><ul><li>Nice dinner: $15-30 USD</p><ul><li>Budget hotel: $30-50 USD/night</p><ul><li>Mid-range hotel: $80-150 USD/night</p><ul><li>Uber ride (20 min): $3-6 USD</p><ul><li>Museum entry: $3-8 USD</p><p><strong>Tipping:</strong></p><ul><li>Restaurants: 15-20%</p><ul><li>Hotel housekeeping: 50-100 pesos/day</p><ul><li>Taxi: Round up</p><ul><li>Tour guides: 100-200 pesos</p><ul><li>Taco stands: Not expected, but appreciated}

Safety Reality Check

{<strong>The Truth About Safety in Mexico:</strong></p><p>Yes, Mexico has crime—like any country. But tourist areas are generally safe, and millions of Americans visit annually without incident.</p><p><strong>Safe Tourist Areas:</strong></p><ul><li>Cancún, Playa del Carmen, Tulum</p><ul><li>Mexico City (tourist zones)</p><ul><li>Puerto Vallarta, Los Cabos</p><ul><li>Oaxaca, San Miguel de Allende</p><ul><li>Mérida, Guanajuato, Guadalajara (centro)</p><p><strong>Basic Precautions:</strong></p><ul><li>Use Uber/DiDi instead of street taxis at night</p><ul><li>Don't flash expensive jewelry or electronics</p><ul><li>Stay in tourist areas, especially at night</p><ul><li>Don't carry large amounts of cash</p><ul><li>Be aware of your surroundings (like anywhere)</p><p><strong>Common Concerns:</strong></p><ul><li>Petty theft: Possible but preventable with normal awareness</p><ul><li>Scams: Tourist traps exist—negotiate prices, research in advance</p><ul><li>Cartels: Active in some regions but almost never affect tourists in tourist zones</p><ul><li>Police: Generally helpful to tourists; avoid bribes if possible</p><p><strong>What NOT to Do:</strong></p><ul><li>Don't buy drugs (seriously—this is how tourists get in trouble)</p><ul><li>Don't drive at night in remote areas</p><ul><li>Don't ignore travel advisories for specific regions</p><ul><li>Don't resist if robbed (stuff is replaceable, you're not)</p><p><strong>Bottom Line:</strong> Use common sense. You're statistically safer in Cancún than in many US cities.}

Cultural Essentials

{<strong>Understanding Mexican Culture:</strong></p><p><strong>Time & Pace:</strong></p><ul><li>Life moves slower—embrace it</p><ul><li>'Ahorita' means 'right now' but could be in an hour</p><ul><li>Being 15-30 minutes late is culturally normal</p><ul><li>Meals are leisurely, especially lunch (comida)</p><p><strong>Social Customs:</strong></p><ul><li>Greet people warmly—'Buenos días' goes a long way</p><ul><li>Physical contact is more common (handshakes, cheek kisses)</p><ul><li>Family is central to Mexican life</p><ul><li>Mexicans are genuinely hospitable</p><p><strong>Eating Culture:</strong></p><ul><li>Lunch (2-4pm) is the main meal</p><ul><li>Dinner is often late (8-10pm) and lighter</p><ul><li>Tacos are eaten with hands, other dishes with fork and knife</p><ul><li>'Buen provecho' (enjoy your meal) is said when passing diners</p><p><strong>Religion & Respect:</strong></p><ul><li>Mexico is predominantly Catholic</p><ul><li>Cover shoulders/knees when visiting churches</p><ul><li>The Virgin of Guadalupe is deeply significant</p><ul><li>Day of the Dead is a celebration, not morbid</p><p><strong>What Mexicans Appreciate:</strong></p><ul><li>Any attempt to speak Spanish</p><ul><li>Interest in their culture and history</p><ul><li>Respect for traditions</p><ul><li>Not assuming Mexico = just beaches and tacos}

Language Tips

{<strong>Do I Need Spanish?</strong></p><p>In tourist areas, you can get by with English. But basic Spanish opens doors and wins hearts.</p><p><strong>Essential Phrases:</strong></p><ul><li>Hola (OH-lah) — Hello</p><ul><li>Gracias (GRAH-syahs) — Thank you</p><ul><li>Por favor (por fah-VOR) — Please</p><ul><li>¿Cuánto cuesta? (KWAHN-toh KWES-tah) — How much?</p><ul><li>La cuenta, por favor — The check, please</p><ul><li>¿Dónde está...? — Where is...?</p><ul><li>No entiendo — I don't understand</p><ul><li>Más despacio — More slowly</p><p><strong>Apps to Download:</strong></p><ul><li>Google Translate (download Spanish for offline)</p><ul><li>Duolingo (start learning before your trip)</p><p><strong>Pro Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Attempt Spanish first, then switch to English if needed</p><ul><li>Smiling and pointing works in a pinch</p><ul><li>Learn numbers 1-100 for shopping/prices</p><ul><li>'Mande?' is the polite way to say 'what?' (not '¿qué?')</p><p><strong>Where English is Common:</strong></p><ul><li>Resort hotels and tourist restaurants</p><ul><li>Cancún Hotel Zone, Los Cabos resorts</p><ul><li>Tourist attractions</p><ul><li>Younger generations in cities</p><p><strong>Where You'll Need Spanish:</strong></p><ul><li>Local neighborhoods</p><ul><li>Small towns</p><ul><li>Market vendors</p><ul><li>Taxi drivers (most)}

Getting Around

{<strong>Transportation Options:</strong></p><p><strong>Within Cities:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Uber/DiDi:</strong> Available in most cities, safe, affordable</p><ul><li><strong>Taxis:</strong> Use official sitio (stand) taxis or have hotel call one</p><ul><li><strong>Metro:</strong> Mexico City's is excellent and cheap ($0.30)</p><ul><li><strong>Walking:</strong> Mexican cities are very walkable</p><p><strong>Between Cities:</strong></p><ul><li><strong>Buses:</strong> First-class buses are comfortable, safe, and affordable (ADO, ETN, Primera Plus)</p><ul><li><strong>Flights:</strong> Budget airlines (Volaris, Viva) connect major cities cheaply</p><ul><li><strong>Car rental:</strong> Good for road trips (Baja, Yucatán), less ideal in cities</p><p><strong>From Airport:</strong></p><ul><li>Prepaid taxi from official booth (safest for first-timers)</p><ul><li>Private transfer (book in advance—worth it for families)</p><ul><li>Uber (works at some airports, not all)</p><ul><li>ADO bus from Cancún airport (budget option)</p><p><strong>Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>Book bus tickets online at ADO.com.mx or Busbud</p><ul><li>For domestic flights, Volaris often has $50-100 fares</p><ul><li>Don't drive at night</p><ul><li>Use toll roads (cuotas) when driving—worth the cost}

Health & Hygiene

{<strong>Staying Healthy:</strong></p><p><strong>Water:</strong></p><ul><li>DON'T drink tap water</p><ul><li>Bottled water is cheap and everywhere</p><ul><li>Ice in restaurants is usually purified (made from purified water)</p><ul><li>Brush teeth with bottled water if you're concerned</p><p><strong>Food Safety:</strong></p><ul><li>Street food is generally safe at busy stalls</p><ul><li>Eat where locals eat (high turnover = fresh food)</p><ul><li>Wash hands frequently</p><ul><li>Peel fruits or wash with purified water</p><p><strong>Montezuma's Revenge:</strong></p><ul><li>Stomach upset happens to ~30% of visitors</p><ul><li>Usually mild and passes in 1-3 days</p><ul><li>Stay hydrated (electrolytes help)</p><ul><li>Bring Pepto-Bismol and Imodium</p><ul><li>If severe or lasts 3+ days, see a doctor</p><p><strong>Sun & Heat:</strong></p><ul><li>Sunburn is the #1 tourist ailment</p><ul><li>Use SPF 30-50, reapply often</p><ul><li>Stay hydrated (more than you think)</p><ul><li>Take breaks from midday sun</p><p><strong>Altitude:</strong></p><ul><li>Mexico City is at 7,350 feet</p><ul><li>You may feel tired or short of breath initially</p><ul><li>Take it easy on day 1-2</p><ul><li>Drink water, skip alcohol first day</p><p><strong>Medical Care:</strong></p><ul><li>Pharmacies are everywhere and can help with minor issues</p><ul><li>Many medications available without prescription</p><ul><li>Private hospitals are excellent (get travel insurance!)</p><ul><li>English-speaking doctors available in tourist areas}

Packing Essentials

{<strong>What to Bring:</strong></p><p><strong>Always:</strong></p><ul><li>Passport (and copy stored separately)</p><ul><li>Travel insurance documents</p><ul><li>Reef-safe sunscreen (required at cenotes/eco-parks)</p><ul><li>Sunglasses and hat</p><ul><li>Comfortable walking shoes</p><ul><li>Light layers (even beach towns have A/C)</p><ul><li>Basic medications (Pepto, ibuprofen, antihistamines)</p><ul><li>Phone charger and portable battery</p><p><strong>Beach Trips:</strong></p><ul><li>Multiple swimsuits (humidity means slow drying)</p><ul><li>Cover-ups for restaurants</p><ul><li>Water shoes for rocky areas</p><ul><li>Waterproof phone case</p><p><strong>City Trips:</strong></p><ul><li>Rain jacket/umbrella (May-October)</p><ul><li>Nicer outfit for restaurants</p><ul><li>Comfortable shoes for cobblestones</p><ul><li>Light jacket for evenings (especially CDMX)</p><p><strong>Leave at Home:</strong></p><ul><li>Expensive jewelry</p><ul><li>Excessive clothes (laundry is cheap)</p><ul><li>Heavy jeans (too hot)</p><ul><li>Anxiety about Mexico</p><p><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> Pack light! You can buy anything you forget, and laundry is $1-2/kg.}

Common Mistakes to Avoid

{<strong>First-Timer Errors:</strong></p><p><strong>Planning Mistakes:</strong></p><ul><li>Trying to see too much (Mexico is HUGE—pick a region)</p><ul><li>Only staying at resorts (you miss the real Mexico)</p><ul><li>Not booking popular restaurants in advance</p><ul><li>Assuming everywhere is hot (CDMX can be cool)</p><p><strong>Money Mistakes:</strong></p><ul><li>Exchanging money at airport (worst rates)</p><ul><li>Not notifying bank about travel (card frozen)</p><ul><li>Carrying only large bills (small vendors can't change)</p><ul><li>Over-tipping or under-tipping</p><p><strong>Cultural Mistakes:</strong></p><ul><li>Calling the USA 'America' (Mexicans are Americans too)</p><ul><li>Expecting everything to run on exact schedule</p><ul><li>Being impatient (rudeness is poorly received)</p><ul><li>Not trying to speak any Spanish</p><p><strong>Safety Mistakes:</strong></p><ul><li>Hailing random taxis at night</p><ul><li>Getting visibly drunk in public</p><ul><li>Flashing expensive items</p><ul><li>Buying illegal drugs</p><p><strong>Food/Drink Mistakes:</strong></p><ul><li>Eating too much spicy food on day one (ease into it)</p><ul><li>Drinking tap water</p><ul><li>Filling up on resort food (street tacos are better!)</p><ul><li>Not trying local specialties}

Trip Planning Timeline

{<strong>When to Book What:</strong></p><p><strong>2-3 Months Before:</strong></p><ul><li>Book flights (prices jump closer to date)</p><ul><li>Book hotels, especially during high season</p><ul><li>Get travel insurance</p><ul><li>Check passport validity (6+ months)</p><ul><li>Notify bank of travel dates</p><p><strong>1 Month Before:</strong></p><ul><li>Book popular restaurant reservations (Pujol, etc.)</p><ul><li>Reserve tours/activities (especially during peak season)</p><ul><li>Download offline maps and translation apps</p><ul><li>Start learning basic Spanish phrases</p><ul><li>Check current entry requirements</p><p><strong>1 Week Before:</strong></p><ul><li>Confirm all reservations</p><ul><li>Print or save digital copies of bookings</p><ul><li>Pack and weigh luggage (budget airline limits!)</p><ul><li>Exchange small amount of pesos (or plan to use ATM)</p><ul><li>Download entertainment for flights</p><p><strong>Day Before:</strong></p><ul><li>Charge all devices</p><ul><li>Check flight status</p><ul><li>Confirm airport transfer</p><ul><li>Pack carry-on with essentials</p><p><strong>Day Of:</strong></p><ul><li>Arrive 3 hours early for international flights</p><ul><li>Have passport and documents easily accessible</p><ul><li>Fill out immigration forms on plane</p><ul><li>Get some cash at ATM upon arrival}

Best Time to Visit

{<strong>When to Go:</strong></p><p><strong>High Season (December-April):</strong></p><ul><li>Best weather almost everywhere</p><ul><li>Higher prices, more crowds</p><ul><li>Book well in advance</p><ul><li>Perfect for beaches and sightseeing</p><p><strong>Shoulder Season (May, November):</strong></p><ul><li>Good deals, fewer tourists</p><ul><li>May can be hot; November is lovely</p><ul><li>Some risk of rain</p><ul><li>Great time to visit</p><p><strong>Low Season (June-October):</strong></p><ul><li>Rainy season (afternoon showers, not all-day rain)</p><ul><li>Best prices and fewest tourists</p><ul><li>Hurricane risk on Caribbean coast (Aug-Oct)</p><ul><li>Green landscapes, dramatic skies</p><p><strong>Special Events:</strong></p><ul><li>Day of the Dead (late October/early November) — Book far ahead for Oaxaca</p><ul><li>Semana Santa (Easter week) — Mexico is on vacation, prices up</p><ul><li>Christmas/New Year — Peak season, book 3+ months ahead</p><ul><li>Spring Break (March) — Cancún gets crazy</p><p><strong>Weather by Region:</strong></p><ul><li>Cancún/Caribbean: Hot year-round, hurricanes Aug-Oct</p><ul><li>Mexico City: Mild year-round, cool mornings, rain June-Sept</p><ul><li>Pacific Coast: Hot summer, perfect winter</p><ul><li>Oaxaca: Mild, rainy summer, dry winter}

Frequently Asked Questions

Is Mexico safe for first-time visitors?

Yes, major tourist areas are safe. Millions of Americans visit annually without incident. Use common sense: stay in tourist zones, use Uber instead of street taxis at night, don't flash valuables, and don't buy drugs. You're statistically safer in Cancún than many US cities. Check travel advisories for specific regions, but popular destinations like Cancún, Mexico City, Puerto Vallarta, and Oaxaca are well-traveled and secure.

Do I need to speak Spanish?

Not required in tourist areas—you can get by with English in hotels, restaurants, and attractions. However, basic Spanish phrases (hello, thank you, how much?) are appreciated and helpful. Outside tourist zones, Spanish becomes more useful. Download Google Translate with offline Spanish before your trip. Mexicans are patient and appreciate any effort to speak their language.

How much money should I bring?

Mexico is affordable. Budget travelers can manage on $50-75/day (hostels, street food, local transport). Mid-range travelers spend $100-150/day (3-star hotels, nice restaurants, activities). Luxury travelers spend $300+/day. Bring a credit card for hotels and nice restaurants, plus cash for tacos, markets, and tips. ATMs give the best exchange rates.

What's the best first destination in Mexico?

For beach + ruins: Cancún/Riviera Maya offers easy resort experience with accessible Mayan sites. For culture + food: Mexico City has world-class museums, incredible cuisine, and vibrant neighborhoods. For beach + charm: Puerto Vallarta combines beautiful beaches with a walkable downtown. For food + culture: Oaxaca is Mexico's culinary capital with rich indigenous traditions. All are safe and tourist-friendly.

Can I drink the water in Mexico?

No, don't drink tap water. Bottled water is cheap and available everywhere—hotels often provide it free. Ice in restaurants is usually safe (made from purified water), and you can generally eat salads and washed produce at established restaurants. Brush teeth with bottled water if you're cautious. This is standard practice for most travelers, and you'll adapt quickly.
